questions.text: Which of these is not a pre-leukemic condition?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria is not a preleukemic condition. 

It is an autoimmune hemolytic anemia due to IgG autoantibodies that bind to the P blood group antigen and cause intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children and show recovery within a month.

Option A: Few patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) develop acute non-lymphocytic leukemia. This is thought to arise from the injured marrow as a secondary hematopoietic disorder.

Option B: Bone marrow aplasia preceding acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a rare condition that usually affects children. It generally follows the recovery of normal blood counts and most commonly occurs within 6 months of the onset of aplasia.

Option C: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) occurs in 10% to 40% of individuals with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). It is usually accompanied by the appearance of additional cytogenetic abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of acute leukemia?

choices.text: Arrest in differentiation and increased  apoptosis
Arrest in differentiation and decreased apoptosis

questions.solution:
In acute leukemia, there is an arrest in differentiation and decreased apoptosis.

Genomic aberrations create oncoproteins. They arrest normal maturation, turn on pro-growth signaling pathways, or protect cells from apoptotic death.

questions.text: As per WHO classification, what percentage of blast cells in bone marrow biopsy is required to diagnose a patient with acute leukemia?
questions.solution:
As per WHO classification, 20% of blast cells must be present in the bone marrow and / peripheral smear for the diagnosis of acute leukemia.

In FAB criteria, the cut-off is more than 30%.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not increase the risk of acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
questions.solution:
Polycythemia vera increases the risk of developing AML, not ALL.

Inherited diseases that are associated with a higher risk of developing leukemias are:

  • Bloom syndrome
  • Fanconi anemia
  • Ataxia–telangiectasia
  • Down syndrome
  • Type-1 neurofibromatosis

Other germline risk factors for the development of ALL:

  • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
  • Familial ALL syndrome

Note: AML has a higher incidence during the neonatal period than ALL among children with Fanconi anemia, Bloom syndrome, and Down syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
questions.solution: Precursor B-cell or pre B cell (previously classified as L1) type is the most common subtype of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a  primary T-cell marker?
questions.solution:
CD10 is not a primary marker of T cells. It is a marker of pre-B cells and germinal-center B cells.

Note:  Although CD10/ Common ALL antigen (CALLA) can be found in B-ALL and T-ALL, it is primarily expressed by pre-B cells and germinal centre B cells. Lymphoblasts of both B and T cell lineages, express CD10 that is lost upon progression to a mature phenotype. It is variably expressed by a few mature B cell tumours. However, the expression of CD10 by mature T cells has not been well established.

 

Related Pearl: Immune Cell Antigens Detected by Monoclonal Antibodies

Immune cells

Antigens associated

T-cell

CD1, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD8

B-cell

CD10, CD19, CD20, CD21, CD23, CD79a

Monocyte or macrophage

CD11c, CD13, CD14, CD15, CD33, CD64

NK-cell

CD16, CD56

Hematopoietic stem cells

CD34
Leukocyte common antigen CD45
Activated B cells, T cells, monocytes, and Reed-Sternberg cells CD30

questions.text: Block-like positivity for PAS on immunohistochemistry of a bone marrow sample is seen. Which of the following cells show this finding?
questions.solution:
Lymphoblasts in acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) show block-like or dot-like PAS positivity. 

Erythroblasts in acute myeloid leukemia-M6 (AML-M6) show diffuse periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positivity.

The image given below shows dot-like positivity for periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) in lymphoblasts.

questions.text: Which of the following cells does not stain positively with Sudan black?
questions.solution:
Lymphocytes do not stain positively with Sudan black dye. Although some positivity may be seen in azurophilic granules of lymphoblasts.

Sudan Black B (SBB) is a lipophilic dye that binds irreversibly to an undefined granule component in granulocytes, eosinophils, and some monocytes.

Related Pearl: Cytochemistry of Acute Leukemias

Stain AML ALL
Myeloperoxidase + -
Sudan black + -
Non-specific esterase

Strongly +ve: M4, M5

Weakly +ve: M3, M7

 _
Periodic acid Schiff +ve in AML M6 +
Acid phosphatase - + (T-cell)

questions.text: What is the most commonly affected gene in patients with T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
questions.solution:
The most commonly affected gene in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) is NOTCH1. 

B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia is associated with mutations of genes such as PAX5, E2A, and EBF. It may be associated with balanced t(12;21) involving the genes ETV6 and RUNX1.

questions.text: A patient with acute lymphoblastic leukemia is found to have t(9;22). What will be the size of BCR-ABL fusion protein produced?
questions.solution:
The size of BCR-ABL protein in t(9;22) associated with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is 190 kDa.

BCR-ABL fusion transcript protein with t(9;22):  

  • Major BCR (M-BCR) 210 kDa size in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) with weaker tyrosine kinase activity 
  • Minor BCR (m-BCR) 190 kDa size in acute lymphoblastic leukemia ( ALL) with stronger tyrosine kinase activity 
  • Micro BCR (μ-BCR) 230 kDa size in myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) with exuberant neutrophilia

questions.text: On immunophenotyping of a patient with early pre-B acute leukemia, which of the following marker will be negative?
questions.solution:
Cytoplasmic immunoglobulins and CD10 are negative in early pre-B acute leukemia but become positive in pre-B ALL.

Related Pearl: Immunophenotyping of Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)

Type of ALL  Immunophenotype 
Early Pre-B ALL  TdT, DR, CD19, CD24 
Pre B ALL  TdT, DR, CD10, CD19, CD20, CD24, Cy Ig 
Common ALL  CD19+,  CD10+/CALLA+ 
Mature B  ALL  DR, CD19, CD20, CD24, Surface Ig 
Pro-T ALL   CD3, CD7 
Pre-T ALL  TdT, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8, CD34 
Mature T ALL  CD2, CD7, Tdt

questions.text: Which of the following is not usually involved in the immunohistochemistry of acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
questions.solution:
Cytokeratin is not a marker of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It is an epithelial cell marker for thymoma.

Tdt, CD1a, and CD3 are markers of ALL.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with fever, weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Your diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with bone marrow histology showing lymphoblasts (condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm) is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. 

ALL is more common in childhood. Clinical features of ALL include:

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies 
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of  large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

Related Pearl: Morphological Characteristics of Blasts Cells in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia vs. Acute Myeloid Leukemia

  Lymphoblasts  Myeloblasts 
Blast population Homogeneous Heterogeneous, with the exception of the undifferentiated form 
Size Variable, mainly small  Variable, mainly large 
Nucleus Central, mainly round; sometimes indented. 
 		 Eccentric, round, oval, or angulated; sometimes convoluted, particularly in the form with a monocytic component 
Chromatin Fine, with dispersed condensation. 
Very condensed in small lymphoblasts 		 Fine, granular, delicately dispersed 
Nucleoli Absent in small lymphoblasts. 
Sometimes indistinct 		 Present. Often large and prominent, double or triple 
Cytoplasm Scanty and basophilic.
Sometimes with a single long projection (hand-mirror cell) 		 Variable. 
Abundant in monoblasts, 
with protrusions in erythroblasts and megakaryoblasts 
Granules Rarely present. Negative for peroxidase, esterases, and toluidine blue  Present in forms with differentiation and positive with cytochemical stains
  • Peroxidase in the neutrophil and eosinophil lineages
  • Nonspecific esterase in the monocyte lineage 
Auer rods Absent  Can be present. 
Typically present in the hyper granular promyelocytic form 
Vacuoles Can be present Can be present. 
Almost always present in forms with a monocytic component 

The image given below shows lymphoblasts.

The image given below shows myeloblasts.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presents with fatigue. His total leucocyte count is 138 x 10^9 / L with 80% blasts on the peripheral smear. Chest X-ray shows a large mediastinal mass. The bone marrow aspirate is as shown below. What would the immunophenotyping of this patient’s blasts most likely demonstrate?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and bone marrow aspirate are suggestive of  T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Thus, immunophenotyping of the blasts would demonstrate an immature T-cell phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive).

The bone marrow aspirate shows lymphoblast with condensed nuclear chromatin, small inconspicuous nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm lacking granules. 

ALL is usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement in 50% to 70%. It has an abrupt stormy onset, within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms.

Clinical features of ALL include: 

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies 
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of  large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

Related Pearl: Immunophenotyping of Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)

Type of ALL  Immunophenotype 
Early Pre-B ALL  TdT, DR, CD19, CD24 
Pre B ALL  TdT, DR, CD10, CD19, CD20, CD24, Cy Ig 
Common ALL  CD19+,  CD10+/CALLA+ 
Mature B  ALL  DR, CD19, CD20, CD24, Surface Ig 
Pro-T ALL   CD3, CD7 
Pre-T ALL  TdT, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8, CD34 
Mature T ALL  CD2, CD7, Tdt

questions.text: In a patient with acute leukemia, the immunophenotype pattern of the blasts is positive for CD10, CD13, CD19, and CD33. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) based on immunophenotyping. 

CD10 and CD19 are markers for B-cell lineage and this patient most probably have B-ALL. Although CD13 and CD33 are myeloid antigens, their expression does not exclude the diagnosis of B- ALL. 

Option B: The diagnosis of mixed phenotypic acute leukemia (MPAL)/ acute leukemia of ambiguous lineage (ALAL) (previously known as biphenotypic leukemia) requires a demonstration of multiple lineages in blast cells. According to WHO's latest update (2022), the requirements for assigning more than one lineage to blast cells are :

 B cell lineage

 
  • CD19 strong: 

    ≥1 expressed CD10, CD22, CD79a

  • CD 19 weak: 

    ≥ 2 or more strongly expressed CD10, CD22, CD79a
T cell lineage  CD3 positive
Myeloid lineage

Myeloperoxidase (MPO) 

OR 

Monocyte differentiation (non-specific esterase, CD11c, CD14, CD64, lysozyme)

In the absence of MPO or evidence of monocytic differentiation, expression of CD13 and CD33 is not sufficient for a diagnosis of MPAL. Hence, biphenotypic leukemia is not the answer here.

questions.text: A patient with weight loss and fever is diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Which of the following is a good prognostic indicator of this condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of t (12;21) indicates a good prognosis in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It involves genes ETV6 and RUNX1.  

Conversely, a translocation involving the MLL gene, t(9;22), and hypodiploidy are associated with a bad prognosis. 

Related Pearl: Prognostic Factors in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

Good prognostic markers  Bad prognostic markers 
Age between 2 and 10 years 

Age younger than 2 years 

Presentation in adolescence or adulthood
Low white cell count  Peripheral blood blast counts greater than 100,000,
Female  Male 
Hyperdiploidy  Hypodiploidy  
Trisomy of chromosomes 4, 7, 10 & 17  Pseudodiploidy or t (9;22)  or t (8;14) or t (4;11) 
 t (12;21)  MLL gene rearrangements 
Early precursor B cell phenotype  T cell phenotype

questions.text:
Bone marrow biopsy of a patient shows > 20% immature blasts with scanty cytoplasm, no granules, and inconspicuous nucleoli. They also stain positive with PAS. Which of the following are good prognostic markers of this condition?
  1. Trisomy 7
  2. Hyperdiploidy
  3. t (8,14)
  4. Pseudodiploidy
  5. Age of 5 years
questions.solution:
The given bone marrow biopsy report is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The good prognostic markers of ALL include trisomy 7, hyperdiploidy, and age of 5 years.
